label.en: The editor and key resource person(s) accept the conditions regarding the use of data documented through WOCAT

helptext.en:
Conditions regarding the use of data documented through the WOCAT

  • Data captured with WOCAT questionnaires will be entered and stored in the WOCAT online database by the editor or a data entry person assigned by the editor. Yet, the editor is responsible for compilation and the data quality. The editor, the resource persons and the data entry person will be recorded and will be given credit for the data in the database as well as in any compilation or publication of the documented technology.
  • Data stored in the WOCAT database are open access.
  • Data is made available for users under the Creative Commons AttributionNonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.

You are free to:

  • Share — copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format
  • Adapt — remix, transform, and build upon the material

The licensor cannot revoke these freedoms as long as you follow the following license terms:

  • Attribution — You must give appropriate credit, provide a link to the license, and indicate if changes were made.
  • NonCommercial — You may not use the material for commercial purposes.
  • ShareAlike — If you remix, transform, or build upon the material, you must distribute your contributions under the samelicense as the original.
  • No additional restrictions — You may not apply legal terms or technological measures that legally restrict others fromdoing anything the license permits.

Full license terms: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/legalcode

helptext.en: Gi: Intensive grazing/fodder production: improved or planted pastures for grazing/production of fodder (for cutting and carrying: hay, leguminous species, silage etc) not including fodder crops such as maize, cereals. These are classified as annual crops (see above).

label.en: If land use has changed due to the implementation of the SLM technology, indicate land use before implementation of SLM technology
Define a specific area / surface for which you will specify costs and inputs

If costs are not calculated per area, specify unit (e.g. dam, meter of stone terrace, etc.)

helptext.en: Time, at which activity is carried out, e.g. month or season, or "after harvest of crops", "before onset of rains", etc.

• Labour costs indicate total person days, either paid or voluntary.
  • Equipment includes tools, machine hours, animal traction, etc. Cost calculation for machine hours should be based on hiring costs – even if the machinery is owned by the land user.
  • Agricultural inputs include seeds, seedling, fertilizer, biocides, compost/manure, etc. and indicate quantities needed
  • Construction material includes stones, wood, earth, sand, etc. and indicate quantities needed

label.en: Production area (new land under cultivation / use)

helptext.en:
Landforms (modified after ISRIC 1993):
  • Plateau / plains: extended level land (slopes less than 8 %).
  • Ridges: narrow elongated area rising above the surrounding area, often hilltops or mountain-tops.
  • Mountain slopes (including major escarpments): extended area with altitude differences of more than 600 m per 2 km and slopes greater than 15 %.
  • Hill slopes (including valley and minor escarpment slopes): altitude difference of less than 600 m per 2 km and slopes greater than 8 %.
  • Footslopes: zone bordering steeper mountain / hill slopes on one side and valley floors / plains / plateaus on the other side.
  • Valley floors: elongated strips of level land (less than 8 % slope), flanked by sloping or steep land on both sides.

label.en: Comments and further specifications on topography (e.g. exact altitude and slope angles of the evaluated sites)
Indicate if SLM technology is specifically applied in convex or concave situations
Comments and further specifications on soils

helptext.en: If available, attach full soil description or specify the available information, e.g. soil type, soil PH/acidity, CEC, nitrogen, salinity etc.)

label.en: Is flooding of the area occurring
Comments and further specifications on water quality and quantity (eg. seasonal fluctuations, source of pollution)

helptext.en: a measure of the diversity within an ecological community that incorporates both species richness (the number of species in a community) and the evenness of species' abundance. It includes all fauna and flora above ground and in the soil (modified after eoearth.org)
refers to the variety or range of habitats in a given region, landscape or ecosystem (modified after oecd.org)

helptext.en: Post-flooding: after rainwater has naturally flooded the field (eg in Wadis, river banks), the water infiltrated into the soil is used intentionally as a water reserve for crop cultivation. The crop(s) use(s) this water reserve for establishment.

helptext.en: Site: A site can be a single plot or a larger area managed by individuals or by a community, or a place where a specific infrastructure hast been implemened (e.g. dam).

If not 100% borne by land user, indicate who funded the remaining costs

Frequency: e.g. annually, each cropping season, etc.

helptext.en: Ge: Extensive grazing land: grazing on natural or semi-natural grasslands, grasslands with trees/shrubs (savannah vegetation) or open woodlands for livestock and wildlife.
forests mainly composed of indigenous trees, not planted by man
forest stands established by planting or/and seeding in the process of afforestation or reforestation

label.en: Which SLM group does the technology belong to?

helptext.en: Ca: Annual cropping: Land under temporary / annual crops usually harvested within one, maximally within two years (eg maize, paddy rice, wheat, vegetables, fodder crops)

Cp: Perennial (non-woody) cropping: Land under permanent (non-woody) crops that may be harvested after 2 or more years, or only part of the plants are harvested (eg sugar cane, banana, sisal, pineapple)

Ct: Tree and shrub cropping: permanent woody plants with crops harvested more than once after planting, and usually lasting for more than 5 years (eg orchards / fruit trees, coffee, tea, grapevines, oil palm, cacao, coconut, fodder trees)
Mf: Agroforestry: cropland and trees
Mp: Agro-pastoralism: cropland and grazing land (including seasonal change between crops and livestock)
Ma: Agro-silvopastoralism: cropland, grazing land and trees (including seasonal change between crops and livestock)
Ms: Silvo-pastoralism: forest and grazing land

label.en: V2: Grasses and perennial herbaceous plants

helptext.en: Eg. fire breaks/reduced fuel
slope of terrace bed <6%
slope of terrace bed >6%
to drain and convey water

label.en: S6: Dams / pans: store excessive water

helptext.en: reducing slope

label.en: M1: Change of land use type
M2: Change of management / intensity level
M3: Layout according to natural and human environment
M4: Major change in timing of activities
M5: Control / change of species composition

helptext.en: if annually or in a rotational sequence as done eg on cropland -> A1
includes recycling, re-use or reduce: includes both artificial and natural methods for waste management

label.en: Wt: loss of topsoil / surface erosion

helptext.en: even removal of top soil, sheet and interrill erosion
deposition of sediments, downstream flooding, siltation of reservoirs and waterways, and pollution of water bodies with eroded sediments
uniform displacement
uneven removal of soil material
covering of the terrain with windborne sand particles from distant sources ("overblowing")

label.en: Cn: fertility decline and reduced organic matter content (not caused by erosion)

helptext.en: eg leaching, soil fertility mining, nutrient oxidation and volatisation (N)
lowering of the soil pH
contamination of the soil with toxic materials
a net increase of the salt content of the (top) soil leading to a productivity decline
deterioration of soil structure by trampling or the weight and/or frequent use of machinery
clogging of pores with fine soil material and development of a thin impervious layer at the soil surface obstructing the infiltration of rainwater
effects of human induced water saturation of soils (excluding paddy fields)

label.en: Ps: subsidence of organic soils, settling of soil
Pu: loss of bio-productive function due to other activities

helptext.en: eg construction, mining, roads, etc
increase of bare / unprotected soil
decreasing vegetation diversity (fallow land, mixed systems, field borders), increased fragmentation of habitats
reduced vegetative production for different land use

label.en: Bf: detrimental effects of fires (includes low / high severity of fires)

helptext.en: on forest (eg slash and burn), bush, grazing and cropland (burning of residues)

label.en: Bs: quality and species composition /diversity decline

helptext.en: loss of natural species, land races, palatable perennial grasses; spreading of invasive, salt-tolerant, unpalatable, species / weeds
decline of soil macro-organisms and micro-organisms in quantity and quality

label.en: Bp: increase of pests / diseases, loss of predators

helptext.en: reduction of biological control
decrease of average soil moisture content

label.en: Hs: change in quantity of surface water

helptext.en: change of the flow regime (flood, /peak flow, low flow, drying up of rivers and lakes)

label.en: Hg: change in groundwater / aquifer level

helptext.en: lowering of groundwater table due to over-exploitation or reduced recharge of groundwater; or increase of groundwater table resulting in waterlogging and/or salinisation

label.en: Hp: decline of surface water quality

helptext.en: increased sediments and pollutants in fresh water bodies due to point pollution and land-based pollution
due to pollutants infiltrating into the aquifers

label.en: Hw: reduction of the buffering capacity of wetland areas

helptext.en: to cope with flooding and pollution
swell (diversion of water flow)
depression (conversion of water flow)

label.en: Land users belonging to a disadvanteged group (e.g. ethnic, religious)

helptext.en: Land used for cultivation of crops (field crops, orchards)
Land used for animal production
Land used mainly for wood production, other forest products, recreation, protection
Mixture of land use types within the same land unit (includes agroforestry)
crop(s) establishment and development is completely determined by rainfall.

the application of a limited amount of water to the crop when rainfall fails to provide sufficient water for plant growth, to increase and stabilise yield; the additional water alone is inadequate for crop production.
any of several means of an artificial regular supply of water, in addition to rain, to the crop(s).

Agronomic measures such as conservation agriculture, manuring / composting, mixed cropping, contour cultivation, mulching, etc.
  • are usually associated with annual crops
  • are repeated routinely each season or in a rotational sequence
  • are of short duration and not permanent
  • do not lead to changes in slope profile
  • are normally independent of slope

Vegetative measures such as grass strips, hedge barriers, windbreaks, agroforestry etc.
  • involve the use of perennial grasses, shrubs or trees
  • are of long duration
  • often lead to a change in slope profile
  • are often aligned along the contour or against the prevailing wind direction
  • are often spaced according to slope

Structural measures such as terraces, banks, bunds, constructions, palisades, etc.
  • often lead to a change in slope profile
  • are of long duration or permanent
  • are carried out primarily to control runoff, wind velocity and erosion and to harvest rainwater
  • often require substantial inputs of labour or money when first installed
  • are often aligned along the contour / against prevailing wind direction
  • are often spaced according to slope
  • involve major earth movements and / or construction with wood, stone, concrete etc.

Management measures such as land use change, area closure, rotational grazing etc.
  • involve a fundamental change in land use
  • involve no agronomic and structural measures
  • often result in improved vegetative cover
  • often reduce the intensity of use
Prevention: good land management practices are already in place on land that may be prone to land degradation. They maintain natural resources and their environmental and productive functions.

Reduction: interventions intended to reduce ongoing degradation and/or halt further degradation. They start improving natural resources and their functions. Impacts tend to be noticeable in the short to medium term.

Rehabilitation/restoration is required when the land is already degraded to such an extent that the original use is no longer possible, and land has become practically unproductive. Here longer-term and more costly investments are needed to show any impact

label.en: excess (e.g. frequent waterlogging, high runoff rates)

helptext.en: crop, fodder, wood/fibre, water, energy
soil, water, vegetation
e.g. droughts, floods, land slides, etc.

label.en: adapt to climate change/extremes and its impacts

helptext.en: e.g. resilience to droughts, storms, etc.

label.en: mitigate climate change and its impacts

helptext.en: e.g. through carbon sequestration
e.g. increase income/employment opportunities
e.g. reduce conflicts on natural resources, support marginalized groups
People move with animals
animal owners have a permanent place of residence where supplementary cultivation is practiced. Herds are moved to distant grazing grounds.
Grazing within well-defined boundaries, movements cover smaller distances and management inputs are higher compared to semi-nomadism.
Carrying fodder to animals confined to a stall/shed or another restricted area; in zero grazing systems the livestock are not permitted to graze at any time
pasture that is sown with a mixture of introduced grasses and legumes (can be fertilized and/or inoculated with rhizobia to fix nitrogen).
Natural and semi-natural forest management: encompasses administrative, legal, technical, economic, social and environmental aspects of the conservation and use of forests.

Plantation management: plantation forests comprise even-aged monocultures and are established primarily for wood and fibre production. They are usually intensively managed and have relatively high growth rates and productivity.

Agroforestry: integrates the use of woody perennials with agricultural crops and / or animals for a variety of benefits and services including better use of soil and water resources, multiple fuel, fodder and food products, and habitat for associated species.

Windbreak: or shelterbelt is a plantation usually made up of one or more rows of trees or shrubs planted in such a manner as to provide shelter from the wind and to protect soil from erosion. They are commonly planted around the edges of fields on farms.

Area closure (stop use, support restoration): enclosing and protecting an area of degraded land from human use and animal interference, to permit natural rehabilitation, enhanced by additional vegetative and structural conservation measures.

label.en: Rotational system (crop rotation, fallows, shifting cultivation)

helptext.en: Rotational systems (crop rotation, fallows, shifting cultivation): is the practice of growing a series of dissimilar/different types of crops/plants in the same area in sequenced season, letting it fallow for a period of time, shifting cultivation is an agricultural system in which plots of land are cultivated temporarily, then abandoned and allowed to revert to their natural vegetation while the cultivator moves on to another plot.

Pastoralism and grazing land management: is the grazing of animals on natural or semi-natural grassland, grassland with trees and / or open woodlands. Animal owners may have a permanent residence while livestock is moved to distant grazing areas, according to the availability of resources
Integrated crop-livestock management: optimizes the uses of crop and livestock resources through interaction and the creation of synergies.
Improved ground / vegetation cover: any measures that aim to improve the ground cover by it by dead material/mulch or vegetation
Minimal soil disturbance refers to no-tillage or low soil disturbance only in small strips and /or shallow depth and direct seeding.
Integrated soil fertility management benefits from positive interaction and complementarities of a combined use of organic and inorganic plant nutrients in crop production.
Cross-slope measures: are constructed on sloping lands in the form of earth or soil bunds, stone lines, or vegetative strips, etc. for reducing runoff velocity and soil erosion

label.en: Integrated pest and disease management (incl. organic agriculture)

helptext.en: Integrated pest and disease management (incl. organic agriculture): Integrated pest and disease management is a process to solve pest and disease problems while minimizing risks to people and the environment.
Water harvesting: is the collection and management of floodwater or rainwater runoff to increase water availability for domestic and agricultural use as well as ecosystem sustenance.

Irrigation management (incl. water supply, greenhouses) aims to achieve higher water use efficiency through more efficient water collection and abstraction, water storage, distribution and water application.
Water diversion and drainage: is the natural or artificial diversion or removal of surface and sub-surface water from an area
Surface water management (spring, river, lakes): involves the protection of springs, rivers and lakes from pollution, from high water flows(floods) or overabstraction of water
Ground water management: involves securing the recharge and the protection from pollution and overexploitation /overuse of the groundwater.
Wetland protection / management: managing wetland typically involves manipulating water levels and vegetation in the wetland, and providing an upland buffer.

Waste management / waste water management: is a set of activities that include collection, transport, treatment and disposal of waste, prevention of waste production and modification and reuse/recycling of waste.
Energy efficiency technologies: reduce the amount of energy required to provide products and services, e.g. for cooking, heating reducing the demand on fuel (fossil, wood)

label.en: Beekeeping, aquaculture, poultry, rabbit farming, silkworm farming, etc.

helptext.en: Beekeeping, aquaculture, poultry, rabbit farming, silkworm farming, etc.: allow food production and agricultural products requiring small surfaces of the land.
Indirect SLM measures are mostly applied within homesteads or settlements, or in specific locations and reduce pressure on the land resources and its negative impacts.
E.g. wood-saving stoves, insulation of buildings) and alternative energy sources (e.g. solar energy, biogas, wind energy, hydropower

label.en: I2: Production of seeds and seedlings, seed selection, production of improved varieties

helptext.en: E.g. tree nurseries, seed banks, etc.

label.en: I4: Bee keeping; smallstock farming (e.g. poultry, rabbits); fish ponds, etc.
I5: Food storage and processing (incl. post harvest loss reduction)

helptext.en: Adapatation: is applied when rehabilitation/restoration of the original state of the land is no longer possible or requires resource beyond the means of land users. This means the state of land degradation is ‘accepted’, but land management is adapted to suit land degradation (e.g. adapt to soil salinity by introducing salt-tolerant plants).

The terms traditional / indigenous / local refer to the farmer's own technologies. They cover technologies in use ever since as well as the ones developed more recently by innovative farmers in response to changing circumstances. Use 'other' when the Technology does not fit any of the given categories and specify which and why it does not fit.

Break down the total costs for establishment. Specify inputs and relating costs in the table below.

If possible indicate costs per input, otherwise estimate percentage of total costs
The information provided on establishment costs (see 5.3) should be based on the activities listed in this question.

label.en: Rating of costs considering the local context

helptext.en:
Agro-climatic zone
  • Humid: length of growing period (LGP) > 270 days
  • Subhumid: LGP 180 - 269 days
  • Semi-arid: LGP 75 - 179 days
  • Arid: LGP 0 - 74 days
The length of growing period (LGP) is defined as the period when precipitation is more than half of the potential evapotranspiration (PET) and the temperature is higher than 6.5° C.
Land ownership is the type of land possession, while land use rights refer to the access to land.

Land use rights / water use rights:
  • Open access: means free for all.
  • Communal (organised): means subject to community-agreed management rules.
  • Leased: right to use land for a limited period of time against payment (contract)
  • Individual: right of use by single user.

Land use rights / water use rights:
  • Open access: means free for all.
  • Communal (organized): means subject to community-agreed management rules.
  • Leased: right to use land for a limited period of time against payment (contract)
  • Individual: right of use by single user.

helptext.en: Please provide a first image of the SLM technology. You can add more images later.
Describe the technology in one sentence containing key characteristics (key words). The definition of a SLM technology is very important for searching the database.

The description has to provide a comprehensive / concise picture of the SLM technology to outsiders and should contain key characteristics such as: purpose, establishment / maintenance activities and inputs, technical specifications, most important conditions regarding natural / human environment, etc. (max. 2500 characters)

label.en: Indicate the country/region/locations where the SLM technology is applied and which are covered by this assessment

helptext.en: The described technology might be applied in various sites. However, restrict information given in this questionnaire to only those sites that have been assessed/ analysed in the documentation process (through field visits, interviews with respective land users, reports, etc.). Do not include other sites where the same technology is applied but no data has been collected.

label.en: Indicate the main purpose(s) of the SLM technology (land user's perspective)
On which current land use type(s) is the SLM technology applied?

helptext.en:
Land use: human activities which are directly related to land, making use of its resources or having an impact upon it.
Land cover: Vegetation (natural or planted) or man-made structures (buildings, etc.) that cover the earth’s surface.

label.en: Specify water supply for the land where the SLM technology is applied
Which SLM group does the technology belong to?

helptext.en: Try to assign the described technology to one of the following SLM groups. In case this is not possible, select several (max. 3) groups to represent the technology.

label.en: Indicate the main types of land degradation addressed by the SLM technology

helptext.en:
Summarize technical specifications, e.g.:

  • Dimensions (height, depth, width, length) of structures or vegetative elements;
  • Spacing between structures or plants / vegetative measures
  • Vertical intervals structures or vegetative measures
  • Slope angle (before and after implementation of SLM technology)
  • Lateral gradient of structures
  • Capacity of dams, ponds, etc.
  • Catchment area and beneficial area of dams, ponds, other water harvesting systems
  • Construction material used
  • Species used
  • Quantity / density of plants (per ha)
Maximum 2 answers per question.
Indicate the state of biodiversity on the analysed sites relative to your region/country standards.

label.en: Land user applying the SLM technology

helptext.en: Specify the characteristics of the average/typical land users who apply the SLM technology. Indicate characteristics relative to your region/country standards.
Refer to the total area used per household (leased and owned land), including the land where no SLM technology is applied.

label.en: Who owns the land and what are the land and water use rights?
Indicate the on-site impacts the SLM technology has shown

helptext.en:
• -3: Very negative (- 50-100%)
  • -2: Negative (- 20-50%)
  • -1: Slightly negative (- 5-20%)
  • 0: Negligible impact
  • 1: Slightly positive (+5-20%)
  • 2: Positive (+20-50%)
  • 3: Very positive (+50-100%)

label.en: Provide photos showing an overview and details of the SLM technology (minimum two photos)

helptext.en:
• Provide at least two digital files (jpeg, raw, pdf, ...), i.e. scans from prints or negative/positive films or digital photos.
  • Photos should be of high quality/high resolution and not manipulated or distorted.
  • Explanation (description) is required for each photo submitted!
  • Photos should match the description given in 2.2 and help illustrate the technical drawing in 2.4.
  • Where appropriate, photos should depict the situation before and after or with and without SLM measures.
  • Good photos are crucial for understanding and illustrating the main features of the technology.

Example:

Overview: Fanya juu terraces in a semi-arid area which have developed over time into benches: note well established grass strips along the bunds. (Photo: Hanspeter Liniger)

Detail: Fanya juu bund in maize field after harvest: napier grass strip on upper part of bund, and maize trash in ditch below. (Photo: Hanspeter Liniger)

label.en: Prevention, reduction or restoration of land degradation
Provide a technical drawing and corresponding technical specifications of the SLM technology
General information regarding inputs and costs
Tolerance and sensitivity to climatic extremes or change
Contact details of resource persons and institutions involved in the assessment and documentation of the SLM technology
Declaration on sustainability of the described SLM Technology

helptext.en: Note that WOCAT questionnaires are focussing on the documentation and assessment of SLM practices. Yet, this questionnaire can also be used to describe partly sustainable and non-sustainable land management practices.

label.en: By whom was the technology implemented?
Which SLM measures does the technology consist of?

helptext.en:
SLM measures – the constituents of a technology

SLM measures fall into five categories: agronomic, vegetative, structural, management and indirect measures. Measures are components of SLM technologies. Each technology is made up of one or – very commonly - a combination of measures: For instance, terraces – a typical structural measure – are often combined with other measures, such as grass on the risers for stabilisation and fodder (vegetative measure), or contour ploughing (agronomic measure). For detailed explanations refer to www.wocat.net

Site specific information: Information provided in this questionnaire should strictly refer to the sites that have been assessed / analysed during the documentation of the technology (e.g. through interviews with land users, field surveys, etc.), although the technology might be applied or applicable in a wider area.

Notes to implementation activities, inputs and costs

  • A distinction is made between initial establishment (construction, initiation) and maintenance / recurrent annual activities.
  • Make specific reference to the sites where the SLM documented technology has been assessed and analysed.
  • Indicate all conservation-related activities, inputs and costs (to land users, projects, etc.) of the Technology that are additional to ordinary field operations. In case the ordinary field operations have changed / are part of the Technology (e.g. conservation agriculture) describe all activities.
  • In case the objective is to compare two situations i.e. after / with SLM measures (e.g. conservation agriculture) and before / without SLM measures (e.g. conventional agriculture) fill in two questionnaires.
  • Exclude costs for awareness creation, planning, training, research, and financial / material support (these will be addressed in the Approach questionnaire)
  • Activities, inputs and costs preferably should be indicated per area. In case you chose local area units, indicate conversion factor (e.g. between local unit and hectare). Include not only the area which is directly covered by SLM measures (e.g. the area that is covered with stone walls, tree lines, ditches) but also the area that is indirectly affected / protected by the SLM measures (e.g. the area between stone walls).
  • Where necessary, inputs and costs can alternatively be calculated per unit such as per entity (e.g. dam) or per length (e.g. meter grass strip, meter stone line)
  • Give US dollar equivalent costs against current exchange rate.
  • It may be very difficult to determine the costs of a SLM technology. Nevertheless, we ask you to give your best estimate!

Give details of the natural (bio-physical) conditions where the SLM Technology is applied. Make specific reference to the sites where the documented SLM technology has been assessed and analysed. Tick one box per question only, except for slope and soil parameters (see indications below). Use comment sections to specify and provide additional information.

Note: Some of the environmental conditions (e.g. slope angle, soil characteristics, water quality/availability, etc.) may change as a result of the SLM Technology! However, describe the conditions without any impact of sustainable land management!

Assess all impacts in the table below, which are relevant in this case. Give your best estimate if data based on measurements is not available. Negligible means „no significant benefit nor disadvantage". Make use of the "quantity before SLM", "quantity after SLM" and "comments/specify" columns to show evidence and justify your selection as much as possible. Even impacts referring to quality can be quantified (e.g. coliform measurement for water quality). 10% increase (eg of yield) might be judged as a great improvement, nevertheless tick the category little (5-20%), and use "comments" to explain. Only indicate quantity (before/after) if impacts are measured or based on surveys. Those impacts which are not ticked are considered as "not relevant" or "not applicable".
